<span class="ltx_p" id="A3.T10.148.148.29.29.34"><span class="ltx_text" id="A3.T10.148.148.29.29.34.1" style="color:#00B4D8;">The problem statement is straightforward and doesnâ€™t seem to have any hidden complexities. The assumptions made are standard for such problems.</span></span>

<span class="ltx_p" id="A3.T10.148.148.29.29.38"><span class="ltx_text" id="A3.T10.148.148.29.29.38.1" style="color:#00B4D8;">If there were any misinterpretations of the question, it would likely be in the setup. <span class="ltx_p" id="A3.T10.148.148.29.29.43"><span class="ltx_text" id="A3.T10.148.148.29.29.43.1" style="color:#00B4D8;">Indeed, the power density of a human is significantly higher than that of the sun.</span></span>
<span class="ltx_p" id="A3.T10.148.148.29.29.44"><span class="ltx_text" id="A3.T10.148.148.29.29.44.1" style="color:#00B4D8;">Final check of the calculation steps and logic. The approach of equating the power density of the modified sun to that of a human and then using the Stefan-Boltzmann law seems correct.</span></span>
</span>
